reviewText:
Alluring & difficult to put down // Recommended for critical thinkers and casual gamers alike
~Full Disclosure: This game was reviewed with a key given by the developers~
+ Each 'tile' feels uniquiely designed, and sets it aside from other titles of the genre that often settle for uniform tiles and grids
+ Absolutely incredible musical score; very melodic, and really pulls you into your chair
+ Random events keep one on one's toes, often doling out punishment instead of reward
+ One of the most important strategic elements involved is that of resource management; the game pulls this off successfully, despite there only being three essential resources to balance
+ Tutorial is well-woven into the early plot, and does an excellent job of introducing the game's mechanics
+ Hand-illustrated artwork is superb, particularly the storyboard pages that are use to advance the plot
+ Permanent death of one's characters is in effect; this does much to lend gravity to one's decisions, and it elicits a nervous reluctance to sacrifice your units (which will often be absolutely necessary)
+ There is actually a commendable amount of character development afoot; this is certainly refreshing for a strategy game
+ Forces must be properly utilized, not only in terms of proper dispersion and front line management, but also in using them to reorganize territories, post-liberation
+ The challenge builds substantially after the initial stage, getting the hook into newer players relatively early on
+ Disney-esque art style contrasts wonderfully with the dark tone pervading throughout
+ Class system is basic enough that one will pick it up quickly; the impact of its utilization is the critical component in your success on the battlefield, and is overall solid in its implementation
+ Equipment management, character stats, and the experience system are all par-for-the-course; nothing revolutionary, but it certainly adds to the depth of gameplay without feeling out of place

- Replenishment of enemy forces, while effective in creating a sense of urgency, can be horribly unforgiving on larger maps
- Unit lists expand awkwardly when attempting to select from the stack; feels a bit odd, in that it can be hard to get the right number of characters within the cursor's selection box, as they move outward when passing over them
- New recruits have a small pool of models to draw from
- There is no skirmish or custom-battle mode; in fact, although the main campaign is very well-done, the game would be well-suited to host more in the way of game-modes in the future (until that is implemented, there is limited replayability)

reviewText:
Alright, two hours into this bad boy, and I'm comfortable reviewing.

Highlands is a Risk-esque resource management/strategy game with RPG elements, to lay it out at its core. While the pics provided up there might make you think it's very simple, there's a lot more depth than I thought there would be.

Gameplay: You have armies that you shift around different areas, and the entirety of your army are heroes. There are four classes: combatants, leaders, academics and mechanics. Combatants' sole purpose is to fight, to add greater numbers to your army. Leaders develop the lands they're on, allowing those lands to generate resources for you. Academics heal your people, simply put. Mechanics fortify areas and also craft items that can be equipped by your heroes. As they level up, they get stronger, acquire different skills and increase in health. You can carry a few minor heroes over with you between games, usually the best leveled ones.

For those who've played Risk, the battling is very much like that. Force on force. Now, you need to get used to two things: you're going to lose heroes, and you're going to lose land. I've seen a couple reviews mention this game is hard, and while it is, it becomes easier once you realize both lands and minor heroes are disposable. Heroes become disposable (the non-important ones, anyways), so you usually shift the brunt of damage to them, while trying to win a battle of attrition and keep your strongest units and critical units intact. In fact, the entirety of this game is a battle of attrition. You fortify some places that serve as choke points, while leaving other lands open so you can lure armies in away from the big armies sitting next to them.

Sounds easy so far, right? Well, not so fast. Every...I think it's 9 turns, enemies populate every land the enemy owns on the map. Never enough to truly be of concern, but enough to reinforce the big armies and keep you on your toes with the smaller lands so that you don't lose something you didn't mean to lose. There are also warlords, who are generated every once in a while and move through the map just like you are. It keeps the pace up and ensures that unless you're sitting at the end of the map, you're gonna have to keep moving and keep attacking.

All in all, it turns into a much more complex strategy game than I was expecting, though I still think a little more flexibility needs to be in the actual combat itself.

Aesthetic: As you probably suspect, the aesthetic is very well done. While the music isn't quite Supergiant-esque, it's still adds a pleasant ambience to help keep you frothing at the mouth in frustration. The cartoonish graphics are great, even in the more grim moments I've seen across the game. There's really nothing to nitpick at here, though I do wish there more character designs for each class. I know that there are dozens of designs across the classes, but considering how many heroes you just throw away, I think there needs to be more variety. Especially in combatant.

Story: The story is quite simple, but enjoyable nonetheless. The characters aren't completely one dimensional, but aren't exactly complex either, which isn't necessarily a bad thing. The game has its little random events here and there, and there are little scenes at the end of each map that are well written enough. I will say that I have spotted some errors here and there within the script. Nothing laughable, but another look-over by an editor wouldn't have hurt. In case you're curious, there's no voice acting that I've seen so far, outside of the opening.

All in all, I'd say this is a good game if you're looking for something not too complex, but challenging. If you're looking for something very in depth, you might want to watch some LPs to decide if this will be enough to scratch that itch.

reviewText:
Highlands is a turn-based strategy RPG with a simple but engaging design and beautiful hand drawn art. Its unique style really draws you into the gameworld and its story of warfare among floating islands in the sky.

The game's basic mechanics involve a game of territorial control, where you freely assign various characters from your army among different 'sectors' on the map to capture them from enemies, defend your own territory, or use abilities. Capturing new sectors generally opens you up to further attacks, forcing the player to balance between expansion and defense. The RPG side of the game presents you with a number of different character types who each have different abilities: pure combat strength, healing, fortification, and leaders who convert sectors for you. I only wish the actual combat between armies was a bit more involved; it basically comes down to who has the most/biggest guys and a few dice rolls without much in the way of tactical choice.

This is definitely a game worth playing for RPG or strategy enthusiasts, and my biggest regret is that it isn't longer.

You can also check out a longer review at the DecryptedGaming blog here[decryptedgaming.com].

reviewText:
A surprising little strategy gem. This is a turn-based strategy game that owes more to abstract wargames than it does to the likes of Final Fantasy Tactics or King's Bounty, complete with somewhat esoteric game mechanics, abstraction of combat, and emphasis on supply lines and areas of control. But where I usually find the gameplay of grand war games to be inaccessible at best, Highlands' mechanics are clean and simple to understand, and within a couple of chapters I found myself adroitly maneuvering my units toward victory.

The good:

The art is gorgeous, hand-drawn cel-style, and while the character portraits and chapter interstitials aren't animated, they don't really need to be: the art stands well enough on its own.

The game mechanics are unique, but not obtuse. I found them easy to understand and manipulate, and I really enjoyed the feeling of mastering a new and unfamiliar system by the end of the game. If you enjoy learning systems, this will scratch that itch.

On the Challenging difficulty (second-hardest out of four), the game is--apropriately enough--challenging, but not frustrating. I rarely felt like I was being handed a victory, and the objectives and parameters of each of the game's seven chapters mix it up enough that I kept having to devise new strategies.

The game moves at a very fast clip. The only downtime you'll ever really experience is when you're contemplating your next turn. Menus are smooth and fast, though I did find that the item/equip menu was a little clunky. Animations are fast, clean, and descriptive, and the game tells you everything you need to know and doesn't dilly-dally about it.

The meh:

The music is okay, but nothing exceptional. It's mostly inoffensive, light, airy background music. It fit the theme and accompanied the game well, but I don't think I'll be humming it months from now.

There is a fair amount of RNG in this game, as the outcome of combat is determined by a dice roll modified by the combatants' relative combat strength. The game's tutorial does a good job of instructing you on how to gain the edge in combat, but you may well run into situations where you have to rely on an against-the-odds roll in your favor to proceed. The game is generous with autosaves, but you may end up save-scumming a few battles if you're particularly unlucky.

The writing is servicable at best. It gets the job done, but it's mostly exposition dumps and the characters never develop much personality. The copy editing is rather poor, too; time and again I saw missing punctuation and bad sentence structure. The developers would have been wise to hire a line editor to mark up their script beforehand. The pacing is also awkward. In short, don't play the game for its writing or story.

Conclusion:

Despite its flaws, I really enjoyed the time I spent with the game. I thought it was just the right length, it provided just the right challenge, and was engrossing enough that the hours flew by while I was playing. I would recommend this game to anyone with an eye for strategy games, especially anyone who is interested in learning new systems.

reviewText:
Highlands plays a lot like Risk, but has some really interesting elements to it that balance the gameplay and difficulty out.  In Risk, and Civilization, once you gain the upper hand the game is as good as won, and it's an unmotivated steamrolling of whatever's left in the game, which can really drag on.  In Highlands, taking a slower paced strategy can actually work against you, as every few turns there are respawns that get higher over time.  The third chapter in particular I had to restart because I wasn't aggressive enough at the beginning, and got boxed in and overwhelmed.  The resource management is pretty basic, but works well and plays a vital role to your success.  I felt like some abilities were slightly overpowered, but then on the last stage I realize it would have been impossible without them.  I think great attention was given to the overall balance of the game.

It falls a bit short on the story, and overall length.  It's about 15 hours total.  It lacks any kind of customization beyond a limited set of equipable items, which even on the weapon side is a one size fits all selection.  Level ups are important, but  adding a character attribute to advance each level would have added a ton of replayability to the game.

In summary, if you are looking for a quick, easy to learn, addictive turn based strategy game, this is an easy choice.  It has that Civilization feel of one more turn" and the difficulty scales really well as you advance in the game.  I personally recommend doing the "Challenging" difficulty level if you are big into strategy games

reviewText:
Highlands is a turn-based strategy set on a series of floating islands. The royal family in this world apparently have quite a set of cojones, as they are on the front lines with their troops the entire time. You can recruit new fodder in taverns littered around the map. There are a multitude of classes available, leaders capture resource points, engineers/mechanics can craft weapons and armor as well as fortifying your points on the map. Combatants are the meatshields, and academics are used to keep the meat on their feet.

Enemy robots and warlords will consistently advance on your position. Luckily your enemies can only move through your areas one at a time, but they do spawn friends after a set amount of turns (depending on the difficulty) which helps to keep the pressure on. There have been multiple situations where I screwed around for far too long capturing points only to be forced into combat with an almost insurmountable force at the end of the map. How did I overcome? Molotovs. Lots and lots of molotovs.

Trying to keep a decent pace while not missing out on crucial resources is indeed a delicate dance, and as with most dances, I fail pretty miserably. Leadership is a resource used to recruit new troops, food is used as upkeep for your troops as well as keeping your characters healed, finally scrap is used in every sort of crafting imaginable. Gearing up your troops with weapons and armor increases their fighting ability, but all the skill in the world won’t save your characters from the ever-looming threat of permadeath.

Random events ensure no game plays out the same, but the story will remain the same. While the events are cool, this along with some flowery writing and amazing visuals don’t really motivate me to give the game a second playthrough. I’m supremely glad I got to experience it, and won’t hesitate to call it another kickstarter success story, but I don’t think I’ll be sitting down to trek through it again, at least for a little while. Fantastic first game by Burrito Studio, we at IGB can’t wait to see what is next.

reviewText:
Highlands is a deceptively simple looking strategy game.  I was drawn in by the gorgeous hand drawn art and the promise of a turn based strategy game with some rpg elements and I have not been disappointed.

The game puts you in charge of the Arislaan  family in a fight to reclaim their kingdom in the sky.  The clouds act as a fog of war and as you fight your way across the regions you gotta look out for both enemies and valuable resources that the regions have to offer.

You have four classes of characters; the combatant is a straight up fighter, the mechanics can build the very important fortifications, the leaders are needed to gain control of areas and finally the academic function as healers. There is a number of special skills that widen the scope of that, but those are the basic functions of the classes.

There are three basic resources; food  that is essential for survival and healing, leadership that allows you to purchase new heroes and finally scraps that you can use to craft items as well as other special stuff.

These simple mechanics make for some tough choices on the battlefield. When to advance. What regions to focus on and to get essential resources or  buildings (taverns to recruit new heroes or workshops to craft items) and so on. On top of that, death is permanent! So if  you loose any of the main characters they are really gone. So be careful.

Controls are simple and work well. The artwork is gorgeous like I said and the music also adds to the mood. So if you like stuff like the old Heroes of Might and Magic or Battle  Isles? Or maybe you enjoy some of the Japanese tactics games? Then this is for you! The combat system may seem simple, but don't be fooled, there is plenty of strategy to sink your teeth into here.

In conclusion, Highlands gives us some much needed turn based goodness. I highly recommend it.

I was a Kickstarter backer for this game, but I honestly didn't think I would enjoy playing it myself. Turn-based strategy games are not usually my thing. So I was pleasantly surprised to find that I enjoy playing this very much.

The hand-drawn art is gorgeous (although it's hard to read the white text that appears over it and I wish they had given the text a black lining). I also like the intro that plays when you start a game, but I do not like that there doesn't seem to be a way to skip past it or to skip the tutorial aspects during the first chapter. This is a game that I'll want to play multiple times. I do not need a reminder of what each character type can do.

At the same time, the game leaves out important information at times. If an item that you have found or crafted isn't equipped at the end of the level, you lose it. They don't tell you this until after the end of the first level. So I lost a couple items. Nbd though.

Some people have expressed frustration with enemy characters spawning too quickly. The AI can be aggressive and that was overwhelming at first, but that's not an inherently bad feature (I mean, overwhelming enemies is the whole point of Castle Panic, and that's a great game). It's just part of the strategy. Just because enemies are spawning does not mean that you have to defeat all enemies to beat a level. Just a thought. And I have found that it's best to take things sloooowly. Take a few turns to build up your defenses before moving on to the next sector. Stock up on resources and don't be afraid to use your milita skill.

Like the description says, this game is easy to learn, but hard to master. You can choose your level of gameplay, which is cool, because I like to use casual gameplay first and work my way to the top.

Oh, and I have to say this: I hate the royal family! They are so obnoxious. Half the time when they run into people they accuse those people of treason. Stop being a bag of ♥♥♥♥♥, royal family.

Overall, this is a game totally worth buying and it is one of the few games I can say is worth the price (although it never hurts to wait for a sale or a bundle!).

reviewText:
A fun little gem. If you enjoy strategy games then consider letting your eyes linger a while longer.

What I liked

Mechanics: Highlands is a very elegant, very sharp game. At its core is a very simple system of board control and area denial. To gain and hold territory you have four types of units:

Fighters: everyone has a combat value, but fighters have the highest. Enemies will never engage a stack bigger than itself, allowing you to body block territory.
Builders: Fortifies territory, creating a shield the enemy has to eat away at before moving forward.
Leaders: Mobilizes territory under your control, allowing resource production.
Healers: Using limited resources (food), patches up your wounded combatants.
By the end of the first map you've pretty much figured it all out, at which point your characters start gaining new abilities as they level up (crafting, ranged zone control, etc.) and you rush to figure out how to best employ them, because...

Map Design: They've done a great job with campaign progression. As you progress the maps become progressively more challenging as more elements and twists on gameplay are thrown in your path, forcing you to discard old strategies and incorporate those shiny new abilities that seemed excessive only one map ago. A less innovative game would have reused the same basic layout time and time again, and the mechanics would have suffered from it.

Art/Layout Design: The art is gorgeous, and more importantly it meshes very well with the visual information the game needs to present. There is never any excess data in your field of vision, you know everything you need to without cluttering up the screen with too many inputs. Concision is a virtue even in game design!

What I Didn't Like

The Writing: There's no way around it. As addictive as the gameplay is and as beautiful the world they've created is, they really dropped the ball here. Every word out of any character's mouth is the most banal, generic action/fantasy trope they could get their hands on. Maybe you don't care about storytelling, in which case move on, but as some who reads every codex entry I can find in games I was quickly fast-forwarding through any cutscene because my stomach couldn't handle it. It isn't even properly proofread, as characters will overtly contradict earlier events.

And it's a shame. Bad storytelling isn't news, and I usually just ignore it. It's a shame because the world they created isn't just beautiful because of the artwork: the mechanics themselves tell a tale far grander than the writing ever aspires to. You're introduced to the royal family: the daughter of the duke, a burgeoning warrior who wants to be just like her dad. The duke arrives and is this towering figure, with a combat value so much higher that you can't help but believe him to be that archetype of the invincible father present in almost every child's mind. And yet... by the end of the game, the daughter has surpassed him, reached heights even he could not. That is a beautiful story, and not a single word is devoted to it. A tale told entire in numbers.

There are many moments like that in the game, and if they're intentional then I tip my hat to their creators. But given the state of the actual plot, I'm not holding my breath.

Randomness of Combat: Combat is essentially determined by stack size. The bigger your total combat value, the harder your troops hit the other guy's troops, and vice versa. Except that all of this is determined by a ridiculously bounded dice roll. It's not unusual to see a possible roll of 1-120, where anything above 60 will one-shot a Fighter. And since power is adjusted as the battle goes on, the first dice roll is infinitely more critical than any other.

Oh and if any of your main characters die at any time, it's game over. Reloading is never painful, it just brings you back right before the battle, but the whole thing just incentivizes you to reroll until the result is what you need it to be. Later in maps you have the resources to just buy enough disposable characters to eat those first few blows, but it isn't good design.

Luckily the emphasis of the game is in the board mechanics and not the combat, so this isn't a huge issue. But it is one you will notice.

TLDR (Conclusion for the regular folk)

Highlands has a few flaws (story, combat) but when talking about an indie game it's far more important to talk about niche: what does this game do well, and why will I enjoy playing it?

The strategy component of this game, the board control gameplay, is an incredible amount of fun. The mechanics fit seamlessly into one another and have obviously received a lot of care. If that's a game type you enjoy, then you will definitely want to play Highlands.

Note: If you have any experience with this type of game, I recommend playing on Hard. While that may have been what created the excessively random combat rolls (I did not play on normal difficulty so perhaps they are balanced around it), the scarcity of resources and relative strength of the enemy was perfect. Overcoming the challenges presented is the most satisfying part of this game, and you'd be doing yourself a disfavour if you made it easier.

reviewText:
The artwork in this game reminds me of Banner Saga, but the underlying gameplay is much shallower. The setting and characters were good, and the story (though mostly told in prose between chapters) was decent. I especially liked the character designs. The gameplay was interesting to start with but got tedious by the end of the game.

Primarily this is a game about map control and gathering resources, rather than direct combat. This leads to a fast-paced start as you try to defend against enemies on multiple fronts while improving your income. Once you've stabilised though, it's a slow mindless grind through large groups of enemies that have no real chance of breaking through your lines. To make matters worse, the combat consists of random dice rolls with a huge variance. You can see damage ranges of 1-90 odd, which means the enemy could do nothing or one-shot your character. You can mitigate this with character ablities, but they cost resources which means that grinding out the last areas of the enemy is a repetitive cycle. Namely: hit end turn to gather resources, activate skills to capture a location, drop back to heal and gather resources, repeat. Higher difficulties make the early game more frantic, but don't help with this gameplay cycle.

The game is fun enough to last most of its short length, though I recommend avoiding the higher difficulties because the fun of putting out fires at the start of levels is quickly extinguished by how tedious it is to finish off a level.

Difficulty

I will say that if you've experienced playing strategy games beforehand, the game will be noticeably easier as you might recognize the patterns/quirks of the gameplay. I should mention that earlier on, the game was apparently MUCH more difficult, as what is now the Challenging difficulty used to be the Normal mode. After finishing the game once and now starting over, I can say without hesitation that you will see a difference in how much you struggle--I finished normal mode without losing any units or resetting, but now I've lost at least 2-3 people in Chapter 2 alone.
